instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3209: What is 820-3209? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 3 Beeps Issue
threads.message:
Hello,

<CAPACITOR>C7553</CAPACITOR> was shorted (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>). Replaced and now got fan spin, but getting 3 beeps indicating RAM issue?

Battery is connected and it runs off battery just fine.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.4 volts
<SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG</SIGNAL> = 1.359 (low?)
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 1.1 volts
PPCPUVCCIO_S0_REG = 1.08 volts
<SIGNAL>PP0V75_S3_MEM_VREFDQ_A</SIGNAL> = 0.67 volts

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 3.3 volts

How should I begin troubleshooting this?

Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 3 Beeps Issue
threads.message: EDIT: I fixed it by reflowing all the RAM chips. I figured I probably used too high of a temperature for removing the shorted cap on the other side of the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 3 Beeps Issue
threads.message:
STOP to use hot air to change the caps!
Add 138 degrees alloy, or solder paste, on the terminals first.
Then is very easy to remove it with the solder iron.

58 degrees alloy is better.
I did it this way, before getting the JBC tweezer.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 3 Beeps Issue
threads.message:
Thank you for the tip! I will get some ordered.

As for your tweezers, which model do you recommend? I want to look into this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 3 Beeps Issue
threads.message: I have NP105-B and PA120-A; with their corresponding dual station.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 3 Beeps Issue
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 80202, member: 682"]
58 degrees alloy is better.
[/QUOTE]
I cant find info about this.. its bismute? Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 3 Beeps Issue
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 3 Beeps Issue
threads.message: but its solder or flux? i think there is solder who melt with 58 °C... im using 138° bismute. Thanks for your time.. (in ebay only found flux chipquik)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 3 Beeps Issue
threads.message:
The alloy is Bi58Sn42 and time ago was posted as 58 degrees melting point (by some sellers).
Its melting point is 138 degrees in fact, sorry for my error about 58 degrees.

[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.ebay.es/sch/i.html?_from=R40&_trksid=p2334524.m570.l1313&_nkw=chip+quik+alloy&_sacat=0&LH_TitleDesc=0&_odkw=chipquik+alloy&_osacat=0[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 3 Beeps Issue
threads.message: Aaaaaaaaaahhhhhh yep.. 138° i have it.. thanks =)
